turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Ten grand. I'm gonna win ten grand in one night.  ...Well, who's gonna beat me? C'mon, Charlie, who's gonna beat me?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Okay... Okay. Nobody can beat you.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Ten grand! I mean, what other poolroom is there in the country where a guy can walk out with ten grand in one night? Jeez, you know, I can remember hustling an old man for a dime a game.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: How do you feel?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fast and loose, man.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: In the gut, I mean.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I feel tight -- but good.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Quit. He's too good.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Charlie, I'm gonna take him.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, how much are we ahead?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Approximately? One thousand bucks.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fats, let's you and I shoot a game of pool for a thousand dollars a game.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How much we got?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Eleven thousand four hundred, cash. Here in my pocket.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Preacher, go on down and get me some breakfast, will ya? Egg sandwich and a cup of coffee. You want something, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Now wait a minute. You're coming with me. You're gonna eat breakfast at the hotel. Pool game is over.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, it isn't, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Eddie...

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: The pool game is over when Fats says it's over.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You wanted ten thousand? You got ten thousand.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Ah, get with it, will ya, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Get with what?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You can't see it, can you, Charlie? I mean, you've never been able to see it. I came after him. And I'm gonna get him. I'm goin' with him all the way. The pool game is not over until Minnesota Fats says it's over. Is it over, Fats?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Twenty-five hours, Eddie. Twenty- five hours you been playin' straight.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Give me a drink, will ya?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You don't need a drink.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Will you shut up... Just give me a drink.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What are you trying to do, Eddie? You beat him. You beat him bad. You wanna kill yourself?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What are ya, chicken, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well, maybe that's it. I'm chicken.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Go on home. Just leave me the money.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Go to hell.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Charlie, boy, you better give me that money. C'mon now, give it to me. It's mine.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Okay, here...  Be a damn fool.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Is this all we got left?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: If that's all you got, that's all we got left.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hello, Charlie...  C'mon in...  That's my girl.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hello, Eddie's girl...  I looked all over for you.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh yeah? How'd you find me?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I asked around.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh, I don't want to be no bother to nobody.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, don't play it small, Charlie. It don't look good on you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: How do you want me to play it? I'm broke.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: So am I... Sit down.  Would you get us a couple of drinks?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You walked out on me like that. No goodbye, no nothing. Like a thief in the dark. We were partners. We were more than partners.  He was like a... like --

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: A son.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, like a son.  I've known this boy since he was sixteen. The first time I saw him, back in Oakland, I said, "This is a talented boy. This is a smart boy."

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Talk to me, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I want you to come back on the road with me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Aah! I've got no stomach for that any more. I've had that kind of life.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What kind of life have you got here? Scufflin' around the small rooms, picking up eight, ten bucks a day?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'll connect. I'll get you your money back.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Are you figuring on going back to Ames to play Minnesota Fats again? Is that what's on your mind?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Never been out of it. I'm gonna beat that fat man... with that curly hair, and those diamond rings, and that carnation.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: This boy's crazy. They wiped the floor with him. They beat his brains out and he wants to go back.  What for? To take another beating?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I told you you'd get your money back.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: He thinks I care about the money.  I care about you. Do you care about me, Eddie? We're together a long time, night and day. So how do you say goodbye?  You gimme the car and a hundred bucks. You think I care about the dough, the car? I care about you.  This boy is the greatest pool hustler you ever saw. A real high-class con man. He can charm anybody into anything. Did he ever tell you how well we were doing on the road? We had everything: we ate good, we slept late, we had money to burn. Whisky, dames...  Excuse me...  I'll tell you what -- take her along.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: With what?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't worry about it. I'll raise the money.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh yeah? Where?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What's the difference where? I'll raise it.  Is it all right if I have another drink?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: HOW MUCH?!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: My twenty-five per cent. Approximately fifteen hundred bucks.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, you crumb. With that fifteen hundred I coulda beat him. That's all I needed, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Aw, Eddie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: C'mon, c'mon, just give me the money.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What for? To play Fats again?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, to play Fats again.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You wanna come back on the road with me, okay, the money's yours. But if you wanna give it to Minnesota Fats... nothing doing. What do you say?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You still don't see it, do you, Charlie? You are nothing but a small- time Charlie. You'd love to keep me hustling for you, huh? Wouldn't ya? I mean, a couple more years with me, scuffling around them little towns and those back alleys. You might make yourself enough to get a little poolroom back in Oakland. Six tables and a handbook on the side. Is that when you say goodbye to me, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Is that what you think?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, that's what I think.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: All right. That's what I want. Poolroom with a little handbook on the side. Getting old.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Lay down and die by yourself. Don't take me with you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Just like that?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. Just like that.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, no more for me.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Well, hello. Haven't seen you in a long time.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Findley.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Glad to meet you.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: And I you.  I think I've heard about you, Mr. Felson. You play pocket billiards, don't you?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Now and then. Why, do you?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: A little, although I'm afraid I generally lose.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: I'll bet you do, Mr. Felson. I'll just bet you do.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Bert, I believe Mr. Felson's making a proposition.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: You're very direct, Mr. Felson.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: That's right. When?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Would you like to come out tonight?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What time?

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: I'm having some people over for drinks right after the races. Why don't you all come over? Then about nine, ten o'clock we can play.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: You gentlemen care for a drink?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, none for me. Come on, let's play.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: By all means.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I thought we came here to play pool.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: I don't play pool, Mr. Felson. I play billiards. My house, my game. You don't have to play if you don't want to.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Beautiful shot, Felson. Beautiful. You've played billiards before, Mr. Felson. Ah, you gentlemen sure you don't care for a drink?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh no, nothing for me.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Like to raise the stakes, Mr. Felson?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Okay?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: There it is. I'm broke.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Ah, that's unfortunate, Mr. Felson.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: For who, Mr. Findley? ...Bert, he only beat me by one point. Now, you can't get off me now.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Here.  Been an interestin' evening.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, sure has.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Charles, will you call a cab for these gentlemen, please.  I'd show you to the door, but I...

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh yeah, yeah. You're tired.  And beat.

turns.speaker: FINDLEY
turns.text: Yeah. You must come again.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. Sure.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, uh, mister? Hey, okay if I grab a cue?

turns.speaker: PLAYER
turns.text: Hey, you're Eddie Felson, aren't you?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Who's he?

turns.speaker: PLAYER
turns.text: Now, look, fella, I saw you playing at Ames the other night.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey, I'll tell you what -- I'll play you jack-up pool -- just keep one hand in my pocket.

turns.speaker: PLAYER
turns.text: Oh man, you're way out of our league.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's the limit?

turns.speaker: PLAYER
turns.text: Half and a dollar.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Gimme ten bucks.

turns.speaker: PLAYER
turns.text: Ten dollars.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How much you playin' for?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: A dollar on the five, two on the nine.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, I'll play you a couple. Just for kicks.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Okay, friend.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: You quittin' too?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You're a pretty good player.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: How much are you ahead?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Couple of bucks.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: I guess it's just you and me, huh?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, I guess it is, boy. Just you and me.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: You wanna raise the bet? Two on the five, five on the nine?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You know what, kid? I think maybe you're a hustler.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Try me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Shoot.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: You sure you don't want to quit, friend?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Let's cut out the small stuff, huh? Hundred dollar freeze-out. Ten games, ten bucks a game, winner take all. And then we'll see who quits.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Okay, friend. You're on.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Call it.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Heads.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: You better not miss, friend.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I don't rattle, kid. But just for that I'm gonna beat you flat.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You quittin', friend?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Yeah, I'm quittin'.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Long wait for a bus?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How long you been waiting?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How long have you been waiting?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Since four.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Just a cup of black coffee, please...  Hey, ma'am! Wait a minute!  Would you, uh, like another cup?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Fine, thanks.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What time does the bus leave?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What bus?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yours.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Eight o'clock.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That wouldn't give us much time, would it?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, you're right. I guess it wouldn't.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Have a nice trip.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Thanks. I will.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Have a nice trip?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Fair.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Can I sit down?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why not? We already know each other's secrets.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Thanks for the, uh, for the breakfast.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Two ships that pass in the night should always buy each other breakfast.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Can I buy you another drink?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It's the lights. And the scotch.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: How come you didn't catch your bus?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I wasn't waiting for a bus.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Then why go to the bus station?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Same reason you went: at that hour of the morning you haven't much choice. Besides, I only live three blocks from there. Where do you live?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Around.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I know where you live: in a locker, in a bus station. What's it like living in a locker?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Cramped.  You always drink like this, so early in the morning?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Do you always ask so many questions?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, not always.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Sometimes I wake up and I can't sleep, not without a drink. The bars don't open until eight. Mack over there has faith in me. When I'm broke, he trusts me. Don't you trust me, Mack?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You talk kind of funny, but I like it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I used to be an actress.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah? What do you do now?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm a college girl. Two days a week, Tuesdays and Thursdays, I go to college.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You don't look like a college girl.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm the emancipated type. Real emancipated.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, I didn't mean that -- whatever that means. I mean, you just don't look young enough.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm not.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: So why go to college?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I've got nothing else to do on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What do you do on the other days?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I drink.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No. No more. I'm getting sleepy.  Thank you very much, Mr...?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Eddie. The name is Eddie.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: The name should be Eddie. What should my name be?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I don't know. Whatever you like it to be.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I like it to be what it is. It's Sarah. That's a biblical name. You want to know its meaning?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I could always get us a bottle.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fifth of scotch?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What do you want me to do, just step out in the alley? Is that it?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No. I'll take you home.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why did you do that?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I wanted to see what kind of a day it is.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: A day like any other. People come, people go.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Give me a drag.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Eleven o'clock... I'll be back later.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh, you need a shave. You mustn't go looking like that. There's a razor and shaving cream in the bathroom. Compliments of the house.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What did you say that for, Sarah?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: How did you know my name was Sarah?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You told me.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I lied. When I'm drunk I lie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Okay. So what's your name today?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Sarah.  Eddie, look. I've got troubles, and I think maybe you've got troubles. Maybe it'd be better if we just leave each other alone.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I got my things over at the hotel. I'll bring them over later...  Come here.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm not sure... I don't know.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, what do you want to know? And why?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Where you been all day?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: At school. It's Thursday.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, I forgot.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You were asleep when I left. I didn't want to wake you. Did you go out?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah, I went out for a couple of hours.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You know, I've been living here for almost three years. Now in three days it seems as if I know everybody. When I pass people on the street I want to stop and say, "Listen, I got a fella."

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Eddie, where do you go when you go out?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Museums... art galleries... concerts.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, I believe you when you say you go to school.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You want to go with me?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What, are you kidding? See that book?  I've been trying to get through that book ever since I first got here. I haven't finished the first chapter.  Did you read all them books?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Mm hmm.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You got it all in your head?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: When I'm sober. They get a little mixed up when I'm drunk. Most of the time they're mixed up.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, stop talking about yourself like you're a lush or something. I don't like it.  Maybe you ought to go to a clinic, get some treatments.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm getting treatments right here.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Take your choice. I've got enough so we won't have to go out of the house till Tuesday.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What did all this stuff cost you?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: When you've got money, you'll pay.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, c'mon, I wanna know. I wanna keep score.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: The bills are right here. You didn't say what you wanted.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Don't you ever cook anything?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Eggs. How do you like them?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Raw.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh, cut my finger.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I've got something in my bag.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh, it's not bad.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Eddie, what's in that case?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Haven't you opened it?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No, why should I? It's yours.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: It's a machine gun. This guy told me when I came to the big city I'd have to have a machine gun, so I bought one.  Where do you get the money? To pay for all this? I mean the liquor, and the groceries, and the rent?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: From a rich old man who used to be my lover.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Do you want me to go?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No, stick around.  Can I get you something? Drink? Coffee?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You going out?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. For a little while.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What are you writing?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh, it's a story. A story I'm making up.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Give it to me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's this supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Give it back to me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's this supposed to mean: "We have a contract of depravity. All we have to do is pull the blinds down."

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You told Charlie to lay down and die. Will you say that to me too?  What happens, Eddie?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You'll find yourself another rich old lover.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That's right! And I'm sure you'll help me.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Me. It's Eddie.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I got beat up. They...  They broke my thumbs.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You can read it, if you want to.  You want to go out for a while? To a movie?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You wanna drink?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No. You?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: What's it so hot in here for?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Sarah, do you think I'm a loser?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: A loser?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. I met this guy -- Gordon, Bert Gordon. He said I was. Born loser.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Would he know?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: He knows. A lot.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why did he tell you?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I don't know. I'm not sure. He said there are people who want to lose, who are always looking for an excuse to lose.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What does he do, this Bert Gordon?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: He's a gambler.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Is he a winner?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, he owns things.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Is that what makes a winner?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, what else does?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Does it bother you? What he said?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah.  Yeah. It bothers me a lot.  'Cause, you see, twice, Sarah -- once at Ames with Minnesota Fats and then again at Arthur's...  ...in that cheap, crummy poolroom... Now, why'd I do it, Sarah? Why'd I do it? I coulda beat that guy, I coulda beat him cold. He never woulda known. But I just had to show 'em, I just had to show those creeps and those punks what the game is like when it's great, when it's really great. You know, like anything can be great -- anything can be great... I don't care, bricklaying can be great. If a guy knows. If he knows what he's doing and why, and if he can make it come off. I mean, when I'm goin' -- when I'm really goin' -- I feel like...  ...like a jockey must feel. He's sittin' on his horse, he's got all that speed and that power underneath him, he's comin' into the stretch, the pressure's on him -- and he knows -- just feels -- when to let it go, and how much. 'Cause he's got everything workin' for him -- timing, touch. It's a great feeling, boy, it's a real great feeling when you're right, and you know you're right. It's like all of a sudden I got oil in my arm. Pool cue's part of me. You know, it's a -- pool cue's got nerves in it. It's a piece of wood -- it's got nerves in it. You feel the roll of those balls. You don't have to look. You just know. Ya make shots that nobody's ever made before. And you play that game the way nobody's ever played it before.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You're not a loser, Eddie. You're a winner. Some men never get to feel that way about anything. I love you, Eddie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You know, someday, Sarah, you're gonna settle down. You're gonna marry a college professor, and you're gonna write a great book. Maybe about me, huh? Fast Eddie Felson, hustler.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You need the words?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes, I need them very much. And if you ever say them I'll never let you take them back.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You glad?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes, I'm glad.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Sherry.  Very old, very dry.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Two.  Sherry?... Nice joint. You look very pretty.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I feel pretty.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, what's so funny?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Your tie. I never saw you wear one before.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: First time for everything.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What is it, Eddie?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Nothin'.  Want another drink?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What do you want to tell me?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, I, uh, I'll be leaving town for a little while.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: For how long?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, I don't know.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: A week? A year?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: More like a week. Look, I'll be back.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Sure. Let's go home.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No, I want to walk.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Come here. Come on, now.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Don't you want to know where I'm going?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No.  Yes, I want to know what for. But I don't want to ask.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'm going to Kentucky. To Louisville. With a friend. Try to make some money. I need it, the money. I'll be leaving early in the morning.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Leave now.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, grow up.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why should I?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Sarah, I'm going to Kentucky to play pool, with a guy by the name of Findley. Now, I need the action and I need the money. I told you I'd be back.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: If you were going to come back you wouldn't have taken me out tonight. You wouldn't have bought this dress. You're hustling me, Eddie. You've never stopped hustling me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Now, I never hustled you. Even when I thought I was. You know it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What do you want me to do? Just sit here and wait? Faithful little Sarah. Pull the shades down and sit. When you feel like coming back, you'll come back. And you'll love me. And then you'll go away again. Is that your idea of love?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I got no idea of love. And neither have you. I mean, neither one of us would know what it was if we saw it coming down the street.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'd know it, Eddie. I'd know. For God's sakes, what are you trying to do to me? I love you.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, what's your idea of love? Chains?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No.  I made you up, didn't I, Eddie? You weren't real. I made you up, like everything else. There was no car crash, Eddie. When I was five, I had polio. I was never an actress. The rich old man is my father. He walked out on us when I was seven. He sends me a check every month. That's how he buys his way out of my life. The men I've known... after they left, I'd say they weren't real, I made them up. But you, Eddie. I wanted you to be real.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Fifty-seven.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'll be up later.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Where's Bert?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: He went off someplace.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, that old lovin' horse paid twenty-two forty.  Let's see... two hundred I won from the jockey last night. And today at the track... I got five hundred and forty bucks.  Here, you hold it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Just for luck.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: If you don't mind I think I'll stay at the hotel.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, what's the matter?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm a little tired.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Go on back to the hotel.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Please, Eddie, don't beg him.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Would you go on back to the hotel? Take a cab, go on back to the hotel.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Doesn't all of this come through to you, Eddie? Doesn't any of this mean anything to you? That man, this place, the people. They wear masks, Eddie. And underneath the masks they're perverted, twisted, crippled.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Don't wear a mask, Eddie. You don't have to.  That's Turk, Eddie, the man who broke your thumbs. Only he's not going to break your thumbs. He'll break your heart, your guts. And for the same reason -- 'cause he hates you, 'cause of what you are. 'Cause of what you have and he hasn't.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Would you get off my back, Sarah? Once and for all, will you get out, will you GET OFF MY BACK?!

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Now and then. You know how it is.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You're, uh, you're Minnesota Fats, aren't you? You know, uh, they say Minnesota Fats is the best in the country out where I come from.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Is that a fact?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yes sir, boy, they, heh, they say that old Fats just shoots the eyes right off them balls.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Where do you come from?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: California. Oakland.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: California? Is your name Felson? Eddie Felson?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: I hear you've been looking for me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Yeah. That's right, too.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Big John! You think this boy is a hustler?

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Do you like to gamble, Eddie? Gamble money on pool games?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fats, let's you and I shoot a game of straight pool.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Hundred dollars?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Well, you shoot big-time pool, Fats. I mean, that's what everybody says, you shoot big-time pool. Let's make it two hundred dollars a game.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Now I know why they call you Fast Eddie. Eddie, you talk my kind of talk...  Sausage! Rack 'em up!

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Boy, he is great! Jeez, that old fat man. Look at the way he moves. Like a dancer.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Twelve. Cross side.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: And them fingers, them chubby fingers. And that stroke. It's like he's, uh, like he's playing a violin or something.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Nine ball.  Three ball.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Your shot.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You miss?  Well, you don't leave much when you miss, do you, fat man?

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: That's what the game's all about.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Mm hm... Two ball, side pocket.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Very good shot.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You know I gotta hunch, fat man. I gotta hunch it's me from here on in... One ball, corner pocket.  I mean, that ever happen to you? When all of a sudden you feel like you can't miss? I dreamed about this game, fat man. I dreamed about this game every night on the road... five ball...  You know, this is my table, man. I own it.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Preach! Go down and get me some White Tavern whisky, a glass, and some ice.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Preacher! Go on down and get me some bourbon. J. T. S. Brown. No ice, no glass.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Preach... get it at Johnny's.  You got a bet.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fats, I got about two hundred dollars here.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Game's over, Eddie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Fats, look, I got about two hundred dollars here. You can't run out on me.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: You watch me.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I came to play pool, Fats.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: That's good, Eddie. For how much?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You name it.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Thousand dollars a game.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Let's make it three thousand dollars a game, Fats. C'mon, three thousand dollars. That's my bankroll, my life's savings.  What's the matter, Fats? All you gotta do is beat me the first game and I'm on my way back to Oakland.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: Shoot pool, Fast Eddie.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I'm shootin' pool, Fats. When I miss you can shoot.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: I quit, Eddie. I can't beat you. Willie, give him the stakes.  You got yourself a pool player.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Preacher, gimme my coat, will ya?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: ...you shoot a great game of pool.

turns.speaker: FATS
turns.text: So do you, Fast Eddie.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You -- think I am -- I'm --  -- an animal.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: I can't live like you do -- all your machines and -- cold metal and sharp corners --

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: You lived like this once.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: That is not now, human!

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: My name is Robert.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: It is not arguing to speak the truth.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Listen to me, my blood somehow... helped you.  It could help all of you.  We could find some way to --

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Do you want to go on?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: How much do you remember?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: It comes back.  Flashes.  My name.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Do you remember where you lived?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: It was warm.  I was outside.  The ocean?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: What about... now?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: With them?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: We move.  Place to place.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: When you're here, in the city, where do you live?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Dark and large.  With vines -- no, not vines.  Not alive.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Who is this?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: My wife.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Was this -- "beautiful?"  Before?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Do you remember where it is?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Where you lived with them.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You want to find them.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You want to kill them.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Why don't you start with me?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: You're not them.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: What choice did I have -- ?!

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You hunt us like animals -- do you know how many you have slaughtered?!

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: I only protect myself -- !

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You are The Human.  The Hunter.  The thing that comes in the day and kills --

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: If I'm a hunter it's because you taught me to be!

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You know what I mean.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Will you keep feeding me?  How long can you live like that?  Until it kills you?  Until I kill you? Without your blood I'll go back.

turns.speaker: NEVILLE
turns.text: We don't know that --

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: I know it.  What do you want, Robert?
